'''Aron Burton''' (born June 15, 1938) is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues|electric]] and [[Chicago blues]] singer, bass guitarist and songwriter. In a long career as a [[sideman]] he has played with [[Freddie King]], [[Albert Collins]] and [[Junior Wells]], and has released a number of solo albums, including ''Good Blues to You'' (1999, [[Delmark Records|Delmark]]).<ref name="AMG"/> His own recorded work has been nominated four times for a [[Blues Music Award]] in the 'Blues Instrumentalist - Bass' category.<ref name="Hanson">{{cite book
| first= Karen
| last= Hanson
| year= 2007
| title= Today's Chicago Blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Lake Claremont Press
| location= Chicago
| page= 106
| isbn= 978-1-893121-19-5}}</ref>

==Biography==
Burton was born in [[Senatobia, Mississippi]], [[United States]].<ref name="AMG"/> He sang in a number of local churches, and was a co-founder with his cousin of the group, the Victory Travelers. Burton relocated to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], in 1955. His musical career commenced the following year, playing the bass backing for [[Freddie King]].<ref name="Earwig">{{cite web |url=http://www.earwigmusic.com/aron-burton/ |title=Aron Burton |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Earwigmusic.com |accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref> King purchased Burton's first [[bass guitar]].<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p61191/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Aron Burton |author=Dahl, Bill |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref> 

Burton served in the [[United States Army]] between 1961 and 1965, but upon discharge found employment variously playing with [[Baby Huey & the Babysitters]], [[Junior Wells]] (with whom Burton toured between 1969 and 1972)<ref name="Hanson"/> and [[Fenton Robinson]]. Burton also undertook  recording sessions with [[George "Wild Child" Butler]], [[Jackie Ross]] and [[Carey Bell]] (''Heartaches and Pain'', 1977).<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Center"/>  Burton also recorded a solo [[Single (music)|single]], "Garbage Man", which was released by Cleartone Records.<ref name="AMG"/>

In 1978, Burton joined his brother, Larry, in [[Albert Collins]]' backing band, the Icebreakers, and Burton appeared on Collins's [[Grammy Award]] nominated album, ''[[Ice pickin'|Ice Pickin']]''.<ref name="Hanson"/> He also toured with Collins before leaving his ensemble in the early 1980s.<ref name="AMG"/>  In the meantime, Burton worked as a horticulturist for twenty years in [[Garfield Park (Chicago park)|Garfield Park Conservatory]], under the auspices of the [[Chicago Park District]].<ref name="Hanson"/> Burton found further work playing with [[James Cotton]], [[Johnny Littlejohn]] and Fenton Robinson (again), before relocating to Europe for a time in the late 1980s.  Whilst there, Burton recorded ''Usual Dangerous Guy'', with [[Champion Jack Dupree]] playing the piano accompaniment.<ref name="AMG"/>

By the early 1990s, Burton had returned to Chicago, and Earwig Records issued the [[compilation album]], ''Past, Present, & Future'' (1993).  It included material recorded between 1986 and 1993, both in Europe and the United States, and established Burton as a [[frontman]] rather than supporting musician.<ref name="AMG"/> Burton appeared at the [[Chicago Blues Festival]] in 1994, where he was joined on stage by [[Liz Mandville Greeson]].<ref>{{cite book
| first= Karen
| last= Hanson
| year= 2007
| title= Today's Chicago Blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Lake Claremont Press 
| location= Chicago
| page= 158
| isbn= 978-1-893121-19-5}}</ref>  She also sang on a couple of tracks of Burton's [[live album]], ''Aron Burton Live'' in 1996, which was recorded at [[Buddy Guy]]'s [[nightclub|club]], 'Legends'. The following year, Burton and his brother played at the Chicago Blues Festival.<ref name="Center">{{cite web |url=http://www.centerstagechicago.com/music/whoswho/AronBurton.html |title=Aron Burton |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Centerstagechicago.com |accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref> This led on to [[Delmark Records]] releasing ''Good Blues to You'' in 1999.<ref name="AMG"/>

Burton co-wrote a track on [[Too Slim and the Taildraggers]]' 2000 album, ''King Size Troublemakers''.<ref name="Credits"/>
